trans-unit.source: MapReduce with Hadoop on HDInsight | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: MapReduce with Hadoop on HDInsight | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to run MapReduce jobs on Hadoop in HDInsight clusters. You'll run a basic word count operation implemented as a Java MapReduce job.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to run MapReduce jobs on Hadoop in HDInsight clusters. You'll run a basic word count operation implemented as a Java MapReduce job.

trans-unit.source: In this article, you will learn how to run MapReduce jobs on Hadoop in HDInsight clusters.
trans-unit.target: In this article, you will learn how to run MapReduce jobs on Hadoop in HDInsight clusters.

trans-unit.source: We run a basic word count operation implemented as a Java MapReduce job.
trans-unit.target: We run a basic word count operation implemented as a Java MapReduce job.

trans-unit.source: Hadoop MapReduce is a software framework for writing jobs that process vast amounts of data.
trans-unit.target: Hadoop MapReduce is a software framework for writing jobs that process vast amounts of data.

trans-unit.source: Input data is split into independent chunks, which are then processed in parallel across the nodes in your cluster.
trans-unit.target: Input data is split into independent chunks, which are then processed in parallel across the nodes in your cluster.

trans-unit.source: A MapReduce job consist of two functions:
trans-unit.target: A MapReduce job consist of two functions:

trans-unit.source: Mapper: Consumes input data, analyzes it (usually with filter and sorting operations), and emits tuples (key-value pairs)
trans-unit.target: Mapper: Consumes input data, analyzes it (usually with filter and sorting operations), and emits tuples (key-value pairs)

trans-unit.source: Reducer: Consumes tuples emitted by the Mapper and performs a summary operation that creates a smaller, combined result from the Mapper data
trans-unit.target: Reducer: Consumes tuples emitted by the Mapper and performs a summary operation that creates a smaller, combined result from the Mapper data

trans-unit.source: A basic word count MapReduce job example is illustrated in the following diagram:
trans-unit.target: A basic word count MapReduce job example is illustrated in the following diagram:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>HDI.WordCountDiagram</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>HDI.WordCountDiagram</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The output of this job is a count of how many times each word occurred in the text that was analyzed.
trans-unit.target: The output of this job is a count of how many times each word occurred in the text that was analyzed.

trans-unit.source: The mapper takes each line from the input text as an input and breaks it into words.
trans-unit.target: The mapper takes each line from the input text as an input and breaks it into words.

trans-unit.source: It emits a key/value pair each time a word occurs of the word is followed by a 1.
trans-unit.target: It emits a key/value pair each time a word occurs of the word is followed by a 1.

trans-unit.source: The output is sorted before sending it to reducer.
trans-unit.target: The output is sorted before sending it to reducer.

trans-unit.source: The reducer sums these individual counts for each word and emits a single key/value pair that contains the word followed by the sum of its occurrences.
trans-unit.target: The reducer sums these individual counts for each word and emits a single key/value pair that contains the word followed by the sum of its occurrences.

trans-unit.source: MapReduce can be implemented in a variety of languages.
trans-unit.target: MapReduce can be implemented in a variety of languages.

trans-unit.source: Java is the most common implementation, and is used for demonstration purposes in this document.
trans-unit.target: Java is the most common implementation, and is used for demonstration purposes in this document.

trans-unit.source: Languages or frameworks that are based on Java and the Java Virtual Machine (for example, Scalding or Cascading,) can be ran directly as a MapReduce job, similar to a Java application.
trans-unit.target: Languages or frameworks that are based on Java and the Java Virtual Machine (for example, Scalding or Cascading,) can be ran directly as a MapReduce job, similar to a Java application.

trans-unit.source: Others, such as C# or Python, or standalone executables, must use Hadoop streaming.
trans-unit.target: Others, such as C# or Python, or standalone executables, must use Hadoop streaming.

trans-unit.source: Hadoop streaming communicates with the mapper and reducer over STDIN and STDOUT - the mapper and reducer read data a line at a time from STDIN, and write the output to STDOUT.
trans-unit.target: Hadoop streaming communicates with the mapper and reducer over STDIN and STDOUT - the mapper and reducer read data a line at a time from STDIN, and write the output to STDOUT.

trans-unit.source: Each line read or emitted by the mapper and reducer must be in the format of a key/value pair, delimited by a tab charaacter:
trans-unit.target: Each line read or emitted by the mapper and reducer must be in the format of a key/value pair, delimited by a tab charaacter:

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Hadoop Streaming</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Hadoop Streaming</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For examples of using Hadoop streaming with HDInsight, see the following:
trans-unit.target: For examples of using Hadoop streaming with HDInsight, see the following:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Develop C# Hadoop streaming programs</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Develop C# Hadoop streaming programs</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Develop Python MapReduce jobs</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Develop Python MapReduce jobs</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: In this example, for sample data, you will use the notebooks of Leonardo Da Vinci, which are provided as a text document in your HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: In this example, for sample data, you will use the notebooks of Leonardo Da Vinci, which are provided as a text document in your HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: The sample data is stored in Azure Blob storage, which HDInsight uses as the default file system for Hadoop clusters.
trans-unit.target: The sample data is stored in Azure Blob storage, which HDInsight uses as the default file system for Hadoop clusters.

trans-unit.source: HDInsight can access files stored in Blob storage by using the wasb prefix.
trans-unit.target: HDInsight can access files stored in Blob storage by using the wasb prefix.

trans-unit.source: For example, to access the sample.log file, you would use the following syntax:
trans-unit.target: For example, to access the sample.log file, you would use the following syntax:

trans-unit.source: Because Azure Blob storage is the default storage for HDInsight, you can also access the file by using /example/data/gutenberg/davinci.txt.
trans-unit.target: Because Azure Blob storage is the default storage for HDInsight, you can also access the file by using /example/data/gutenberg/davinci.txt.

trans-unit.source: In the previous syntax, wasb:/// is used to access files that are stored in the default storage container for your HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: In the previous syntax, wasb:/// is used to access files that are stored in the default storage container for your HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: If you specified additional storage accounts when you provisioned your cluster, and you want to access files stored in these accounts, you can access the data by specifying the container name and storage account address.
trans-unit.target: If you specified additional storage accounts when you provisioned your cluster, and you want to access files stored in these accounts, you can access the data by specifying the container name and storage account address.

trans-unit.source: For example, wasb://mycontainer@mystorage.blob.core.windows.net/example/data/gutenberg/davinci.txt.
trans-unit.target: For example, wasb://mycontainer@mystorage.blob.core.windows.net/example/data/gutenberg/davinci.txt.

trans-unit.source: The MapReduce job that is used in this example is located at wasb://example/jars/hadoop-mapreduce-examples.jar, and it is provided with your HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: The MapReduce job that is used in this example is located at wasb://example/jars/hadoop-mapreduce-examples.jar, and it is provided with your HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: This contains a word count example that you will run against davinci.txt.
trans-unit.target: This contains a word count example that you will run against davinci.txt.

trans-unit.source: On HDInsight 2.1 clusters, the file location is wasb:///example/jars/hadoop-examples.jar.
trans-unit.target: On HDInsight 2.1 clusters, the file location is wasb:///example/jars/hadoop-examples.jar.

trans-unit.source: For reference, the following is the Java code for the word count MapReduce job:
trans-unit.target: For reference, the following is the Java code for the word count MapReduce job:

trans-unit.target: For instructions to write your own MapReduce job, see <linkText>Develop Java MapReduce programs for HDInsight</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.target: HDInsight can run HiveQL jobs by using a variety of methods.

trans-unit.source: Although MapReduce provides powerful diagnostic abilities, it can be a bit challenging to master.
trans-unit.target: Although MapReduce provides powerful diagnostic abilities, it can be a bit challenging to master.

trans-unit.source: There are several Java-based frameworks that make it easier to define MapReduce applications, as well as technologies such as Pig and Hive, which provide an easier way to work with data in HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: There are several Java-based frameworks that make it easier to define MapReduce applications, as well as technologies such as Pig and Hive, which provide an easier way to work with data in HDInsight.
